know a gentleman that has been ſo kind to me. But ſervants muſt obey.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Are theſe Olivia's commands?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſay it, Sir, they are. I am ſtrictly charged to ſhut the door in your face; and may perhaps get turned away, for talking to you. But, ſince it is come to this, I don't much mind if I am.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Go, go, Robert! Obey your orders. (Pauſe)

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Oh Lord! Oh Lord!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Why then the diſſolution of worlds may be foretold; and impoſſibilities are true. Can it be? Holiday friends, ſlaves of appearances, ſycophants of proſperity, that rats like theſe ſhould fly the falling edifice is nothing ſtrange; it moves not my gall. But thou, Olivia? Thou!—It cannot be! 'Tis but ſome generous artifice to try my temper; and put my knowledge of thy noble nature to the teſt.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I muſt ſpeak a word of comfort to 'n; and I wul!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And ſhall a ſport, a ſhew of injury, deceive me? From a mind, too, native in magnanimity; incapable of inſult? What, diſtruſt thee? Rank thee with the baſe, the venal, and the vain? With grovelling ſpirits, that never felt the exalted ſwell of ſouls? Souls that riſe ſuperior to controul; that hold Fate itſelf their ſlave; and make their mirth of their misfortunes? Theſe are thy peers, Olivia. Shall I ſink thee, caſt thee from thy high place in my heart by one degrading thought? Oh no! (Going)

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
I do reverently hoape, Zur, you won't take it amiſs, but if I could be zo happy as to do any
mortal thing, to give you a bit of heart's eaſe, why, juſt at this time, it would make me main light i' my ſtomach here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Thank you, Herbert; but I want no aid.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I do hoape you don't take the baſeneſs of zum volk too much to heart. I do knaw what it is to have a liking vor a zweetheart; and zure enough, if Annabel wur to zarve I o' that'n, I do believe it would make a mazed man o' me!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Have you ſeen Mr. Hudſon?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No, zure. I don't knaw the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, go home. He has ſomething for you.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Won't ee let me go wi' you, Zur? Won't ee? I pray you do! You have a need enough of comfort. Tho'f al the wordle do vorſake you, I do humbly hoape you don't think I be ſo wicked to vorſake you too?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I have no need of your ſervices, my kind friend. When I have, I will accept them.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Wul you? Wul you, Zur? Why then the bleſſings of marcy be wi' you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am happy; be you ſo too. Go home, my good friend. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I do believe a's one of God a'mighty's angels! As zure as can be, a's not o' this arth! Go whoam? But I won't though. I won't go whoam, till I have been into that abomination houſe once more. I do hoape it won't fal, avore I do get out on't! I'll take Annabel away, I'm detarmint! I'll tell madam my mind, come on't what wul!

div.head: SCENE VI. The houſe of CURFEW.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
Why do I make myſelf thus miſerable, for
an unworthy man? Why does my wilful heart regret one who would have fixed it in wretchedneſs?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Dear, dear, Madam, here is poor Herbert in ſuch a taking!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: You know he uſed to adore your very name, and now he is in the bittereſt paſſion with you!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: With me?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: For your unkindneſs to our dear benefactor. He has ſomething at heart that he cannot find words to explain.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Where is he? Bring him here.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Herbert, you may come in.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I don't knaw if I do want to come in. I don't knaw if it beant a zin to be under the zeame roof wi' a falſe hearted—

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Herbert!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: May hap thee do mean to larn o' Madam, and zarve l the zeame? Doee! Doee! That's al! Doee!

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I do adviſe you to know, Herbert, I be no ſuch perſon!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I do hoape i' my heart and zaul thee bean't! I do hoape thee be come of a better breed.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Who is it, Herbert, that you are thus angry with?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I do knaw who! Ees zure! I do knaw who!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Apparently, it is me?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
That your vine volk, that came o' purpoſely
to eat up his very bones, and drink down his heart's blood, that they ſhould turn their backs in his diſtreſs!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why it wur a mortal curſt abomination to be zure! But it wur little more nur natural. I had a vorfeeling o' that!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What do you mean by diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: So kind a wur to ee! Volk may be aſheamed o' theirzel! A would a gin his zaul's eyes to a zaved the little vinger o' thoſe that the moment miſvortin befell'n they ſhut the door in his vace!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What is it you mean?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Where zuch wicked volk do hoape to go to I can't tell! But their end can't be good! No! They can't die in peace!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Herbert, I intreat, I inſiſt, you tell me inſtantly what has happened to Dorington.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Oh, marcy, marcy! As if you didn't knaw! Annabel, I do charge thee come away! If thee doſt ſtay here another night, I'll never zee thee more! I'll make away wi' myzel! I do love thee dearly! Thee doſt knaw I do; ſo come! Thee wilt take pattern to learn a bad zample. I do knaw thee will! So come!

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: I'll come to thee preſently.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Come along! Come! Will ee come? I'll be my own death elſe! Will ee come? (Pulls her)

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.p: Be quiet, Herbert—Dear, dear Madam, good bye! I love you! Indeed, indeed I do! But Herbert will have me with him. Heaven's bleſſings light upon you!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
That be impoſſible, Annabel! I do wiſh vrom my zaul it war not! But it be, it too zurely be! Madam, I did think ee ſuch a Leady as the
wordle couldn't match! But I'll pray vor you! I can do no more! I'll pray that heaven may grant your precious zaul the grace to repent.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: The paſſion of this honeſt youth is incomprehenſible! What heinous act have I committed, that ſhould excite odium ſo violent, and ſo unfeigned, in his well-meaning and kind heart? (To Robert paſſing through the chamber) Robert! Has Dorington called this afternoon?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Very lately, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Did you open the door to him?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I did, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: And what did you ſay?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I obeyed your directions.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Madam? To ſhut it in his face.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: In his face? How durſt you be guilty of ſuch an outrage?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: It was Mr. Curfew's poſitive order, given in your name, Madam, as you were leaving the room.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: In my name?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I ſuppoſed it was becauſe the poor gentleman is ruined.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: How? When?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: All his Weſt-India eſtates, by a great ſtorm.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Heavens, and earth!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: What is it I hear, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: With ſubmiſſion, Madam, How can I tell what you may have heard?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Is Dorington ruined?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Completely.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: And was that the motive, which you would not explain, for urging my conſent to deny myſelf?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: With all deference, would you deſire a better?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Better! Sir, as my Guardian, I have long ſtruggled to preſerve ſome reſpect for you, but it is no longer poſſible! Better? (Aſide) Demons could not have imagined a worſe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Begging your pardon, Miſs—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Sir, I will not be awed by your angry humility, and an irritable ſpirit of contradiction. You have practiſed deceit upom me: odious pernicious deceit: and have made me an abettor of guilt that I abhor.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Under favour, by ſaving you from ruin.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: By plunging me into the loweſt contempt. By giving me the attributes of a fiend! Shut the door in the face of the unfortunate? Of thee, Dorington? The moſt generous and compaſſionate of men! Whoſe liberal hand and large heart were open to the whole human race! Abandon thee now? No! My actions ſhall vindicate me from the wicked, the foul aſperſion. If my whole fortune can ſave thee, thou ſhalt be ſaved. (She ſits down to write.)

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I venture to ſuppoſe, Madam, you will firſt aſk my advice.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: No, Sir; I will not. I have followed your advice oftener than it was good. I will be guilty of this weakneſs no more.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I humbly preſume, Miſs Olivia, you are my ward. (Pauſe) Are you not? (Pauſe) With all due deference to your contemptuous treatment, I expect an anſwer. (Pauſe) Excuſe my freedom, your impertinence deſerves puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Robert! Take this letter to Mr. Conſol, wait for an anſwer, and I particularly requeſt you will be quick! For heaven's ſake, fly!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: (Following very angry) Why, Madam! Your pretended apathy is inſolence, Madam! You are in a paſſion, Madam! You are in an abominable paſſion, Madam! You are in a damned paſſion, Madam. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE IX. The houſe of DORINGTON.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Herbert!—My good fellow!—What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Matter enough.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Zounds, why the fool has tears in his eyes! Oh you ſhocking blockhead! Learn of me! Kick care to the devil! There is no blaſt of bad fortune, however black, that has not a white and bright ſpeck in it. Catch at the glorious phantom, you ranting rogue! Purſue it full ſpeed! Hug it, enjoy it, devour it, you happy dog! If it vaniſh one moment, it will flame with double blaze the next! Light up your imagination at it, and be in a conflagration yourſelf, you ſublime roiſter!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Vine talking.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Fine doing, Herbert! Imitate me: realize your raptures; and then you will be the richeſt raſcal on earth! The whole Globe is mine! The pretended owners plow, ſow, and fret. I eat, drink, and enjoy!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: No, no! There be no more joy vor I!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I am the happy man. I am alert! Alive! All ſoul! All fire! All pure ſpirit! I never walk the earth: I am in air! I fly! I ſoar! Skim!—Oh damme, you never ſee me in the glums!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: May be not. May hap you do zet as little ſtore by your vriends as the reſt o' this baſe wordle.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Damn the world! I know it is baſe. But is that any reaſon that I ſhould be miſerable? Oh, no, Mr. Devil, you ſhall not have that pull upon me! While I live, the ſun ſhall ſhine: and, if it ſhould be ſnuffed out, I'll create a ſun of my own!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Your zun may ſhine; but other volks zuns be zet.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Whoſe?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Mine. But that be nothing. I ſhall never be happy again, ſo long as I do draa breath! But that don't much matter.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Oh you miſerable mortal! You earth-born booby! But never mind. I will be your doctor: your alchymiſt. I will ſublimate, will ſpiritualize you! Only tell me, where Dorington is?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ah poor gentleman, he be ill enough!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Ill? Damme, how dare he be ill, without my leave? But I have news!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Have you?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: News that will make his heart leap!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why have you indeed, Zur? Why have you? Be it good?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Good? A. B. is—The like was never heard!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Laukadaiſy! I be glad to hear it! What can it be?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: A. B.!—I treated him ill laſt night. I refuſed his money. But I am come to make him ample amends! A. B.!—Inſtead of 500l. he ſhall lend me a thouſand!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Lend a thouſand! Marcyful God!—What baſe wretches there be i' this wordle!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Who is baſe, fellow? What is the matter? I know him! To make my fortune will give him rapture! I ſhall repay him all I owe him within a month! Damme, I have been too long in his debt! It is high time to pay off. But I am his friend.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Vriend? Lord vorgi' me! I had liked to ha' zaid, May old cloven foot flee away wi' his vriends, all in a ſtring!—Vriends? Patience o' my heart!—Poor Gentleman! (Wipes his eyes)

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: (Catching tenderneſs) Why!—Herbert. What? Hay?—Speak!—Any—Hay?—Any miſfortune?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: What ull become o' 'n?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Zounds! You tormenting— (His heart full) My good—dear—An—Herbert, ſpeak. Ta ake courage! Be—e—e calm!—Be calm!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: He can't work—He won't beg— (Burſts into a cry) He muſt ſtarve—That's al!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: (Burſting the ſame) Starve? Do-o-orington my frie▪e-end! Da-a-mme if he ſhall!—Wha a at do you cry y y ſo for; you curſt he-e-en hearted dog?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: He that has be en zo goo ood to al!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I kno o ow he has! Wha at then? Wha at then? Da da a amme, don't cry! Doo o o n't cry! You foo ol, do n't cry!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: But I can wo ork vor'n; and zo can A-Annabel.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: And ſo o o can I, you booby! So o can I!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: (Recovering) As long as we a' got a morſel, he ſhall never want! Never!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Want, Herbert! Want? Oh ye immortals! You have ſet my brain in a frenzy! Speak! Speak!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p:
I can't ſpeak—Vorzaken of al his vriends!
His houſe and lands and al blowed down! His zweetheart falſe to her vows! No zaul on earth to comfort his poor heart! What ull become o' 'n?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Death and dam—Blown down?—It muſt be ſo! The great tornado!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Too zure! Too zure!—I ha' but one hoape.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: What is that? My good dear Herbert! What is that?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: May hap you may a' heard of an eſteeate left vor I and my couſin? 'Tis but dree hundred a year. A mortal deeal too much, to be zure, vor I; but almoſt nothing at al, vor he!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: And you would ſhare it, hay; my heroic ſoul?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Share it? Ees zure! Vor it ſhould be every fard'n al his own!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Poiſon and fire! Is not this cutting now? Here is this pitiful claypole will give his eſtate! And I, pennyleſs raſcal that I am, have not a doit to beſtow!—Have not I?—Did I dare tell myſelf ſuch a lie?—Herbert, I applaud the project, my ſoul of benignity! He ſhall have half your eſtate, and all mine!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Al yours! I didn't knaw you had an eſteeate!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Yes but I have, and a noble one it is!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ay vor zure? Whereabouts do it lie?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: In a very narrow compaſs, my boy!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ay ay truly; I do fear as much.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: In a ring fence! Here! (Strikes his forehead) It is portable! Go where I will, I carry it about me! Thieves cannot ſteal! Confiſcation cannot take it away! While I am capable of enjoying, it is certain to be in my poſſeſſion! And, what is better, damme, it is daily riſing in value!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: May hap zo. May hap zo. But I do knaw the lawyers won't gi' five vardins vor the fee ſimple of 't.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You are a royal rogue! But I, I am royalty itſelf.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I do fear you be crack-brained!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I am a genius! And genius is a monarch on a large eſtabliſhment; for whom the public are in duty bound to furniſh a fund of praiſe, equal to his expenditure of intellect!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ay ay! He be too zurely crack-brained!

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: Your name I believe, Sir, is Herbert?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ees zure.

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: And yours, Sir, if I do not miſtake, Mr. Hairbrain?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: (Avoiding him) Zounds! He's a Bailiff!—Well, Sir; and what then?

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: I am glad you are preſent to witneſs that I deliver theſe deeds.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: What? Hay? The eſtate, Herbert! Hay? My honeſt ſetter?

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: On the part of Mr. Dorington. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: As zure as I be I, it is. (Seeks after Dorington)

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Hurrah!—This will be a great day yet. I laſt night dreamt my ticket was come up a blank. Dreams go by contraries! It will be a great day yet! Firſt my prize in the lottery! Then A B! Then the fruits of my own labours! That firſt of delights, that moſt exquiſite moſt certain of reſources, the products of my own genius!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Dang it! Where can a be?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Herbert, my boy! Come! Let us fly! We'll find him.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Leave that to me. I can do every thing. We'll ſettle our property upon him! He'll be very proud! I know him. Ha, ha, ha! What a damn'd booby you were to cry ſo! It will be a great day! A glorious day! Come along! Curſe your crying! Come along! Hurrah! Away! Hurrah! Ha, ha, ha! Damn your crying!

div.head: SCENE XI. The houſe of CONSOL.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Inform Madam Olivia I am come, as ſhe deſired.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Yes! Sir. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p:
I wonder what ſhe can want with me. Not money; for ſhe is rich and has not learned to ſquander. She has ſome deſign. She is very ſmooth ſpoken: a ſure mark of cunning. Oh ſhe has ſome end to anſwer. Odds body! A comical thought has croſſed me! Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! It can be only that! Ha, ha, ha! She has taken a fancy to me! Fallen in love with me! Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! I have hit it! I have the whole clue! I am the rich Conſol! Oh! Beſides now I recollect, I have ſeen her look—I cannot tell how! She knows I am one of the richeſt, ergo, one of the greateſt men breathing! Then there are agreements, ſimilarities between us! She is prudent economical and cunning! So am I: She is rich young and beautiful: ſo am—? Yes—ſo am I! Five and forty is young enough: and as for handſome, your plump, round-faced, ſmug-looking, perſon is always agreeable: and I have a remarkable ſmile—Ha, ha, ha! She is a good one! She knows two and two make four. 'Tis a deep thought!
Her vaſt fortune added to mine, I ſhall ſoon be able to buy up the Bedford rent roll! It is a grand idea!—Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! Oh ſhe is a good one! Zounds, I wonder the thought never ſtruck her or me before! Odds body, it will be a rare match! It will amaze every body! Oh Lord! How happy the diſcovery has made me! Ha, ha, ha! It is a deep game!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Mr. Conſol, I thank you for your immediate attention. I want your aid, and fear I have taken a liberty with you, which you may think ſtrange.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Strange, dear Madam? Allow me to ſay, it is ſtrange you did not take it ſooner.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Take what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: No matter. Better late than never.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I have a buſineſs to propoſe, to which I am but little accuſtomed

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I know it, dear Madam! I know it! But what matters cuſtom?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Good ſenſe, I own, Sir, is a better guide.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: No doubt on't! Be under no alarm, Madam; come to the point at once. I know the world.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Poor Dorington is at preſent in diſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ay, ay! Poor and in diſtreſs. Oh you are a ſhrewd Lady!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I am perſuaded you will not think me ſo.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Dear Madam, I know you to be ſo! I never admired any Lady's prudence ſo much in my life!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I am glad you approve my proceeding.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Approve? I am tranſported with it! I adore you for it! Oh, it was a prodigious thought!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: A very natural one.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: You are a great beauty. So I am a great wit. For why? I can command half a million! Show me another man as witty as myſelf. Then, as for perſon, I have a ſtraight leg, a comely face, and a fine eye, for I always ſee my own intereſt.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I do not comprehend you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nay, nay, dear Madam, ſpeak out, you are ſhrewd: you know well enough modeſty is only a maſk.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: It may be ſo with the knaviſh.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Knaviſh? All people are knaviſh at heart, When they are honeſt it is from a knaviſh motive.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Indeed? Your philoſophy is beyond me.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I hope no offence, Madam? I would rather the ſtocks ſhould fall than offend you!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: (Aſide) What is the matter with the man?—My buſineſs with you, Mr. Conſol, is an affair of delicacy.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Speak; fear nothing, Madam. With the Ladies, no man more delicate than myſelf.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: You are gallant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: To be ſure, Madam! You have made me gallant; have fired me; have put my blood in a blaze!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Mr. Conſol!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Ay, and Mrs. Conſol! Is not that it, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: (Aſide) Is the man frantic?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I ſee you will not ſpeak; ſo I will. I love you, Madam!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: May my Banker break if I do not! Full fifty per cent. better than ever I loved woman in my life!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Amazing!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Not at all. I love you; you love me: there is no love loſt. Our purſes ſhall be as loving as our perſons: one pocket, one pair of ſheets.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! I ſhall expire.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Expire, Madam? I would almoſt rather be a lame duck.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I dare ſay, Sir, your grief would be as pungent as your paſſion is powerful. I know not what odd accident has blown up this flame in your boſom; but I imagine a ſingle word will quench it. You are miſtaken.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Strange as it may ſeem, even you.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: How can that be? You are rich, Dorington is ruined; you are ſhrewd, I am deep; you are a ſpinſter; I am a bachelor. You ſent for me; and having no call for caſh, why did you ſend? To do the deep thing, to be ſure; and couple at once our fortunes and our affections.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha! How ſhall I ſupport this extacy of arithmetic! This profuſion of fifty per cent. tenderneſs?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Nay, Madam—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: This Change Alley Cupid! That ſtudies amorous looks in the price of bullion; paſſionate deſires in correct tables of intereſt; and tumultuous tranſports according to the rate of Exchange! Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I don't underſtand, Madam!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
That falls moſt woefully in love to the quaaking of lame ducks, and the muſic of bulls and bears! That kindles up his flame to the ſweet harmony of ſcrip ſix and a half! Omnium
ten, ſeven-eighths! Who'll buy? Who'll buy? (Laughs)

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Very odd!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Pardon me, Sir. Indeed I would reſiſt this impertinent laugh, if I could.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: What is there to laugh at in me? Fifty thouſand in the long annuities: three times the ſum bank ſtock: and not much leſs in India Bonds, Conſols, and South Sea. Is all that a joke? If it be, it is a deviliſh good joke! One of the wittieſt I ever heard.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I will leave you in full poſſeſſion of your wit and jocularity; and, waving farther preface, declare my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: And am I then really hummed?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: (Shakes her head) Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Are you ſure?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Paſt all doubt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you have miſſed a glorious opportunity; and are not the woman I took you for!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Pray let us be ſerious, Sir. My buſineſs with you requires diſpatch. I want an immediate ſum of money.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Money? That is quite another affair! Money is a very ſcarce article.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: You forget, Sir? Long Annuities, India Bonds, South Sea?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Forget, Oh no! Can't forget! Never forget! But the terms?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Shall be of your own dictating.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Humph! That's ſomething—And the ſecurity?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Is ſurely undeniable.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Oh Lord, Madam! A Ward! Mr. Curfew your guardian! A bill filed in chancery!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I muſt have money, Sir, of you, or elſewhere.

sp.speaker: Con
sp.p: Muſt, I own is an imperious gentleman! Tho' I own I have no diſlike to his acquaintance; for he is always willing to hear reaſon and pay for riſk.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: To be ſure, Sir. (Aſide) Yes, Dorington; I will bleſs even uſury; ſince it will afford thee relief—Pleaſe, Sir, to ſtep into my apartment, and we will agree on the terms.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: I attend you, Madam. But, do now, give the love buſineſs a turn in your thought. Pray do! Really I am a jewel! Do wear me in your boſom.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: (Laughing.) We ſhould be a charming pair!

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: A lovely pair! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE I. The ſtreet.
div.stage: HAIRBRIAN'S lodgings. A tumult without. Enter fellows neatly dreſſed, favours in their hats; butchers in white and blue; Drum-major and Drummers. They all ſound. HAIRBRAIN looks out at the window.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: HOLLA, Holla, Holla! (They ceaſe.) What the devil is all this hallaballoo?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: (Knocks at the door, a girl opens it.) Does Edward Hairbrain, Eſq. live here?

sp.speaker: Girl.
sp.p: Here's an uproar indeed! Who are you? What do you want?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Squire Hairbrain.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: This is ſome damn'd bailiff. Betty! Shut the door! Keep 'em out! I am not at home!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, if you are the gentleman, rare news! Come down! Come down!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You confounded ſcheming raſcals, I tell you, I am not at home! I know your tricks! You are in maſquerade, you dogs!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Come down, Sir! Come down!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Get away, villain! Get away! Or curſe me but I will down with you! I have a four-barrelled blunderbuſs; and, if you offer to ſtorm my Caſtellum, damme but I'll pepper you!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Nay but hear!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I'll let fly! I will! I will!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: (Retreating) I am the head clerk at Fleece|'em's Lottery-office.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: What? Who? Lottery?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: A Prize?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Of twenty thouſand pounds!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Twenty—Take care! Take care! (Deſcends.) Where are you? How many have I killed? Twenty thouſand?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Sterling-money of Great-Britain!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You intolerably lucky dog! Your fortune is made! Twenty thouſand! You inanimate ſcoundrels! Why don't you ſhout? Shout, you dull dogs! Shout!

sp.speaker: Mob.
sp.p: Hurrah! Hurrah! Hurrah!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Play, you villains! Harmony! Heavenly harmony! Silence! Silence, I ſay! Have you brought a coach and ſix?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: No, Sir!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Oh you damned thoughtleſs ſtreet-trotter!

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: But there are twenty on the ſtand.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I'll ride in them all! Call 'em every one! Get within! And without! Upon the roof! Under the wheels! Mount your fiddleſticks and make a cavalcade. Five rounds of beef and as many butts of porter are yours! I'll regale you! Shout, raſcals!—Silence! Once again ſilence! Be mute, villains, and obey! I am the Great Mogul! Take me to my friends! Quick! Quick, you iron-ſouled ſcoundrels! Don't you know he is in diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: Where muſt we go?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p:
Brook-ſtreet, hound! Brook ſtreet! Where elſe, wiſeacre?—I'll be with him! I told him he
might depend upon me. Away! Sing! Shout! Dance! Be mad, you villains! Away! I come, Dorington! I come! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE II. The houſe of DORINGTON.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: The miſtake appears extraordinary!

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: Impelled by inexpreſſible terrors, at the approaching hurricane, I left the iſland before it happened; and eſcaped to the ſhip that brought me to England.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Of whom, then, did you learn the detail you gave me?

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: From various veſſels; that all were uniform in their report. I am ſorry I have unwittingly been the cauſe of ſo painful and falſe an alarm.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Think not of the pain.

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: The intelligence thoſe letters bring is certain. Sheltered by the high lands, your domains received but little damage; and, from the too general devaſtation, your crops, which were great, are doubled in value.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Doubled? No! Let me periſh indeed, rather than batten on the general diſtreſs! Seek a paſſage; return with all ſpeed; and deal out, to the neceſſitous, all the relief my crops and ſtores can ſupply. But let your aid itſelf be cautious, and gradual; elſe, inſtead of good, it may be miſchievous. [Exit Hudſon.

div.stage: Shouting; and then violent and repeated knocking.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What does this mean?—Who is there?—How now?—Why John! Harry!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Dorington!—My friend!—Damme!—I can't ſpeak!— (Recovers) Has honeſt Herbert found you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Found me?—No!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Poor fellow!—I am firſt! The luck is all my own!—Do you know the extent of your riches?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: No, indeed.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I'll tell you. I have brought the account. The balance ſhall be ſtruck inſtantly. Here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What is there?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Your prize.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Among my mad whims, you remember, I one day made you buy a lottery ticket.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For you?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: For me, while you were rich, and I was poor; but now you are poor, and I am rich, for you. In law and juſtice it is all your own.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: (Taking the bills) Have you got a prize?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: No: but you have.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I am heartily glad!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Why that is an honeſt fellow! That is a good fellow! God bleſs you! That is acting like a man! I reverence you!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Well, but hear!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You take it without a word. You don't ſtrike your friend dead by a refuſal! I reverence you! God bleſs you!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My excellent heart! My thrice noble friend!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Yes; we are friends! Everlaſting friends, ſince you have not refuſed me!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Liſten for a moment!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Let me go! What the devil do you hold me for? I have ten thouſand affairs—Why, zounds! Will you let me go?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ned!—Angel-ſouled mortal! Hear! And, if thou canſt, be ſtill more happy than thou art!—I do not want thy money.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Damme!—Cut my throat!—Uſe me tenderly, and blow my brains out!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My eſtates are not deſtroyed!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: (Pauſe) I have deſerved this!—I refuſed your money, and you are ſeeking your revenge!—I deſerve it!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: By all that is juſt and ſincere, I am as rich as ever!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Can you ſo ſolemnly aſſert that which is not?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ay, Ned! Aſk! Can your friend do that?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Why—can—may—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Again and again, I am ſincere!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I can't ſtand it!—My ſoul is ſuffocated! Dorington himſelf again! Give me ſome Burgundy!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And have you a prize?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Damn my prize!—Give me ſome Burgundy!—Lend me your arm!—Dorington!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ned!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I can't ſtand it! [Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE IV. Changes to the hall.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: (Eagerly) Then, Sir, you do not know where Mr. Dorington is?

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: I am in ſearch of him. Not long ſince, I left him at home.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I muſt find him. I am miſerable till I have proved I am not what appearances have made me—You brought the fatal news?

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: I did; and was anxious to prepare him to ſupport the ſhock.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: To which, dreadful as it was, I know him equal.

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: Till then, I had never beheld, nor had any hope any image of, a mind ſo tempered; a heart ſo heroic; a ſoul ſo dignified!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: And I, at the very moment when oppreſſion poured upon him, when the brutal, the wolfiſh, the idiot world deſerted and caſt him forth, I added inſult to outrage!

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: His confidence in you was ſupreme. It ſeemed even to increaſe, by the unmanly taunts, and baſe defection of the ſycophants around him. To you he turned, as to the tried friend of all fortunes. The conſolation it gave him beamed in his countenance.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh God! Oh God! Could I but atone the injuries I have done thee, Dorington, I ſhould die content.

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: Nay, nay, he is ſtill the ſame. His faith in you is not to be ſhaken; not even by your own actions.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: They were not my own. The wickedneſs of fiends is not more hateful to my heart. You, Sir, I know are his tried and truſty agent. Be kind enough to take charge of theſe bills, and deliver him this letter.

sp.speaker: Hud.
sp.p: Pardon me, but I dare not. Neither is it neceſſary. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
He will not, himſelf, give me ſuch a refuſal! His mind is not ſo narrow! My fortune will not reſtore him to what he was; but it will do ſomething.
Of revenge he is incapable. Yes! He is above me!

div.head: SCENE V. Enter HAIRBRAIN, half drunk.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Your humble ſervant, fair Lady!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Sir! Is it you?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Yes: it's me!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Have you ſeen your friend? Where is Dorington?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Dorington is an ex exquis quis quiſite exquiſite fellow! The happieſt dear dog on earth! And I am ſtill happier!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Ay, indeed!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: You are—No—I won't tell you what you are—I won't inſult a woman. But I am ſorry for you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Tell me but where he is, and reproach me as bitterly as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Fie, Madam! I ſcorn re reproach! I never re reproach the Ladies! Never! But I am ſorry for you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Well, well, where is Dorington?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Dorington is a he hero!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Moſt true!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: And I am a he hero! I'm a hero! And yeſterday, yeſtday, I thought you as great a he hero as the beſt of us! So I am ſorry for you! Very ſorry! I am upon my ſoul!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Recollect yourſelf, I intreat you!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p:
Re e collect? You don't ſup up poſe that I am tip ip ſy?—See? What did I ſee? Oh! I could weep a ſea, ay and a tea-cup full of tears! A Lady in dis is treſs of weather always excites my compaſs—ion! My paſſions! It is a mo oving ſcene! I pity you! pity—pit you pit you againſt
any—jil—il—No, damme, Ned, be the Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Shall you ſee him again this evening?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: To be ſure I ſhall, (Turns aſide) unleſs I ſhould happen to get drunk for joy.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Then be kind enough to give him that letter. (Going) From that I hope he will learn the true ſtate of my heart.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Nay, but ſtop! Stop! I have ſomething to tell you.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Concerning Dorington?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Yes. Great news!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: News! What is it? I intreat you ſpeak!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Pro ro ro digious news! I can't find ut utterance!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Endeavour, pray!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I do! I do en—end—End? I haven't begun!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Now!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: His lands and chat—tels were all blown away!—You heard of that?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: I know you did! So you you you were blown away too! Ha, ha, ha! Blown away! All blown away!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Do you laugh at that?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Yes! Ha, ha, ha! Yes I do! For they are all blown back again!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Heavens!

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Every ſtick and ſtone! All in their proper places! As quiet as lambs!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh happineſs! (Recollecting) Yes! Happineſs for him! But what for me?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p:
You thought him poor, and treated treeated him like a—Be quiet, Ned!—Harkye, if ever you ſhould ſee me in my cups, fly! Get out of my
way! I ſhould ſay the ru udeſt bit itter—But, while I am ſober, I only think—I only think you are a bitter—Oh! In my cups beware of me!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Even ſo! Why then he is reſtored to honour and happineſs; and I am fallen into the contempt, the ſcorn, which motives ſo mean as thoſe imputed to me would well have merited! And who will believe them other than they have appeared? When he was poor, I ſeemed to abandon him. Now he no longer needs my friendſhip, I fly to afford him aid!—It muſt not be! He is loſt. Conduct ſo abject as this ſhall never be imputed to me!—And is it thus?—A heart ſo munificent! A ſoul ſo capacious! Manners ſo gentle! Fortitude ſo unſhaken! Is there no hope? Am I for ever cut off from their benignant influence? I am! For ever! He is loſt; and annihilation is come upon my ſoul! [Exit.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Who is loſt? I am not loſt! Here am I!—Why don't you ſpeak?—Think of ſome excuſe—I'll plead for you—I am el el elo eloquent, I am eloquent, and he is noble! Nob oble—So be under no concern, Madam; I, I'll be your meſs eſs meſſmate—Pſhaw! Meſſenger. I'll deliver—Liver? I have the liver hiccup, I believe!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ned! My dear fellow▪ where is Olivia?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Hey day! What the devil! Are you blind? There ſhe ſtands!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Before your eyes! Can't you ſee?—Sobbing and crying! Comfort her! Com um come—Go to her! Take pity on her!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What have you there?

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: An Epiſtle—Ovid—in Arabic—crabbed characters—Thomas! Bring me a wet nap ap kin! A nap ap a nap ſob ſobers me to a mir-a-cle—for I begin to ſuſpect I am how came you ſo?—Do you hear both? I leave you to love and—A wet napkin, Thomas!—Make it up! Be charitable Pa a Paphians Pa Pagans and good Chriſtians—Thomas! [Enter Thomas] A nap a nap—Be quiet. Damme! Do you think I am drunk?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Take care of him, Thomas.

sp.speaker: Hair.
sp.p: Stand off! You mongrel ſon of a plate and trencher! Stand off! Dorington! Be merciful! Conſider! A woman! Oh the dear ſweet creatures! I love 'em from my ſoul! They are the delight, the—I—I—I'd marry them all! (Sings) "With women and wine I defy ev'ry care"—I'd marry them every one!—"For life without theſe"—Marry them all! All!—"Is a bubble of air"—All! [Exit, watched by Thomas.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
(Looks carefully, then ſurveys the letter with anxiety) It is ſealed! But it is directed to me! In her own hand! Why do I feel this palpitation? Do I then at laſt ſuſpect her? Oh no! (Breaks it open and reads.)
Contemning the fetters of prejudice I write the pure feelings of my heart. I have been unintentionally guilty of groſs injuſtice, have liſtened to the malevolent, and have inſulted your exalted character. In you I know my actions will meet a very different interpreter.—I expect you. The door—Oh how I ſcorn my odious conduct!—The door will not be ſhut in your face.
OLIVIA.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p:
How could I forget the letter! 'Twill ſeem
like the meaneſt of cunning. Heavens! What do I ſee?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Olivia!!!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I perceive you have read a letter that was not intended for your peruſal.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Not intended?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I would have died rather than it ſhould have met your eye. It was to the ruined Dorington. I am incapable of the artifice of which it appears to accuſe me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Olivia!—Am I the man to accuſe you of artifice?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Oh Dorington! (She falls on his neck.)

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My ſoul! My heart's precious treaſure!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I thought you poor! Abandoned! I have been heart-broken!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Here huſh your fears! Here bury your diſquietudes!

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Colonel Rampart is below.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh, the Major? Shall we ſee him?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: By all means. [Exit Footman.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Lady Taunton deſires to know if ſhe may be admitted.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Lord Laroon's compliments, Sir, and aſks if you are diſengaged?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sir Pertinax Pitiful's moſt reſpectful congratulations; is inexpreſſibly affected by your return of happineſs, Sir, and underſtanding you were here, requeſts—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Hey day! What homily is this?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: More company, friends of Mr. Dorington, deſire to know if you are at home, Madam.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: No!—Yes! But not at leiſure to interrupt my happineſs by liſtening to the ſneers of malice, or the glozings of hypocriſy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My compliments, Thomas, to the Ladies and Gentlemen. In public, as uſual, I ſhall meet them as acquaintance, but never in private treat them as friends!

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I'll not forget the meſſage, I warrant me.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Colonel, I give you joy of your promotion.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Madam, Dorington is a—Humph? I wiſh I was an Orator! Do you take me? Humph? Hay? Damme! Humph?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Yes, yes; I underſtand you, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Dorington—Caeſar and Pompey? Pſhaw! I wiſh I was an Orator!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I think you are one.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Dorington is my friend. Do you take me? Humph? Were his Majeſty to appoint me Generaliſſimo, I ſhould not be aſhamed of my friend; and I hope my friend will never be aſhamed of me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: There is no fear of that, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.p: Why, yes—Blow me to—I am a Colonel, thanks to ſomebody. Do you take me, Madam? Oh, damme, I wiſh I was an Orator! Humph? Hay? Damme! Humph?

div.head: SCENE IX. ANNABEL timidly at the door: HERBERT pulling her back.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Why, Annabel! Are thee mazed?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I tell thee I will! I know ſhe will forgive us.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Come back, I zay, Annabel! Pize on't! Come back.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I am ſure ſhe will forget our ingratitude!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Nay then, an thee will be muliſh, let I ſpeak—Zur—Madam—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Annabel!

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Herbert!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: I be ſheamed, mortal ſheamed to ſhew my face! But Annabel is nought to blame! It's al the fault of I! Annabel ull break her heart an you don't vargi' her, Madam▪

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I hope you won't be angry with Herbert; he meant it all for the beſt!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: (Aſide) Hold thy tongue, Annabel!—Ees zure! I meeant it al for the beſt! And zo did Annabel. I wiſh I could have zarved you in any zort! I do wiſh it wi' al my heart! And ſo does Annabel! Don't you, Annabel?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Yes! Indeed, indeed I do!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Be quiet! Hold thy tongue, Annabel!—I would a laid down my life! I would as I am a Chriſtian zaul, an I could but a helped to a' meade you both as happy as you do zeem to be: and zo would Annabel! Wouldn't thee, Annabel?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: That I would! Oh! That I would! And I am ſure ſo would Herbert.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Be quiet, Annabel! Zo, as to be zure you mun be angry wi' I, having ſuch good cauſe, wherefore I do beg and pray—Kneel, Annabel—and I do hoape and petition you'll not bear malice wi' Annabel!

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Pray—pray forgive Herbert.

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: My kind, good girl!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: (To Annabel) There! I tauld thee I ſhould compaſs it!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: My gentle-hearted Herbert!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Ees indeed! I wouldn't hurt a worm, not I!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: I love you both!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Do'ee?

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Dearly!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Do'ee?—I tould thee I ſhould compaſs it, Annabel! Didn't I now? Didn't I?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And I would love you ſtill better, if I could!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Would 'ee?—I—love I; not Annabel! I do love ſhe al myzel!—Annabel! I be half out o' my wits! Biſn't thee?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Oh, Herbert!

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: Hold thy tongue! I tauld thee I ſhould compaſs it!

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Come, come, friends—

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.p: There! Doſt thee hear? Vriends! I tauld thee I—

sp.speaker: Oli.
sp.p: Huſband your raptures! Let us be ſober, even in our joys. Let us emulate my nobleminded Dorington! Be full, yet tranquil, in felicity: active, yet ſmiling, in misfortune! Let us reflect on the paſt for improvement, and meet the preſent with equanimity. We ſhall then obtain approbation for our good deeds, and indulgence for our miſtakes. [Exeunt Omnes.

lg.l: TO whining prone, to ſighs and ſobs and tears,
How much is man the creature of his fears!
Hence grief and lamentation long have been
The ſerious ſubject of the comic ſcene.
Nor knew the hero of the doleful tale
To meet miſchance: he knew but to bewail!
Each wind of heaven ſome ſwift deſtruction brought.
The willing ſlave of every brain-ſick thought,
He hunts for woe! For plagues capitulates!
And thoſe he cannot find he ſoon creates.
The thouſand joys he has are all deſpiſed:
The toy he cannot get alone is prized:
Give him but wealth, poor churl, he frets and frowns!
Take it away, poor wretch, he hangs or drowns!
Purſued by phantoms, through life's troubled day,
Coward and fool go with him all the way.
In conſcious rectitude confirmed, and bold,
To-night appears a man of different mould:
Who meets misfortune; fate defies; and braves
The rolling thunder; and the ſurging waves:
Rides ſafe among the rocks, though tempeſt-toſt,
Where many a tall-built bark lies wrecked and loſt.
Poetically rides: but—Thought of fear!
Should one more hurricane o'ertake him, here,
Should burſting yells and howls, from yonder ſkies,
Bid the wild billows of damnation riſe,
Courage and ſkill in vain the ſtorm oppoſe,
He founders in the gulph, and down he goes!
But ſhould you take the helm, and kindly pleaſe
To ſteer, with pleaſant gales, through halcyon ſeas,
The white ſails ſwelling where the zephyrs ſport,
Sweet will the plaudits be that welcome him to port▪
ONCE more I'm ſent, the Poet's Plenipo',
Your high beheſt, dread Potentates, to know.
Say, mighty Monarchs! how ſhall I begin
(Oh that I knew the way!) your hearts to win?
That Critics are unjuſt is falſely rumour'd:
Then ſmile, dear ſweet Sir Gruff! Do look good humour'd▪
Muſt Mr. Bays go hang himſelf? Declare:
Does he deſerve damnation and deſpair?
In gratitude, return of praiſe is due:
You can't imagine how he praiſes you!
He vows, in this moſt great and wiſe of ages,
That this whole audience are Saints and Sages!
Yonder ſits Solomon! Socrates, there!
One queu'd and powder'd: t'other cropt and bare.
This a moſt ſapient Whig; that a ſtaunch Tory.
Their country's mutual boaſt! Old England's glory!
The Greek, a ſtudent in the ſchool of taſte,
Who cultivates the arts by which he's grac'd,
Sports his half-boots; buttons his half-great coat;
And props his chin with wool-pack round his throat:
With bludgeon arm'd, to knock down thoſe that laugh,
He ſallies forth—the Bear and ragged ſtaff!
The Jew—Great Houndſditch never ſaw his peer!—
The cunning Jew, with ev'ry wind can veer.
"I lend my moneeſh, 'cauſe I lofe de Nation
"I join, mit all my art, to pay taxation.
"De Var and Peeſh to me be quite all von,
"Give me but von goot ſhliſh from dat great loaf—d • Loan!"
Yet do not think, proud ſirs, that we ſhall own
The genius we admire is yours alone.
We claim our ſhare. Our taſte, and wiſdom too,
Can equal yours: ſo let us have our due.
We ſtudy the antique! Its ſimple grace
Shines forth in ev'ry form; and ev'ry face!
Thus Lady Candlewick, Sir John juſt knighted,
Prepares for Court. Like turkey-cock bedighted,
With roſy gills, red plumage, pink and muſlin,
And ſcarlet petticoat, the ſattin ruſtling,
She blazes all abroad! As if ſhe came
To ſet the Preſence-chamber in a flame!
Loaded with dignity, and loops, and laces,
The prototype of Wenus and the Graces.
Slim as a Porter butt, tall as a Drum,
With feathers ſix feet high, behold her come!
Beef-eaters ſtand abaſh'd, fall back and ſtare;
She waddles on with ſuch a Greek, Dutch air!
None can diſpute her elegance, and taſte:
All muſt allow my Lady has no waiſt!
Anxious and proud to captivate beholders,
Her hips have juſt join'd iſſue with her ſhoulders!
I prate too long; yet, hear me one word more.
Shall I defy, petition, or implore!
Great is your pow'r; and you know how to uſe it;
None ſure would wiſh, would prompt, you to abuſe it.
Our cauſe is yours; to you that cauſe we truſt:
If merit you perceive, you'll be to merit juſt.
